elements.content: Interaction of zinc or cadmium formate or acetate with 1,2-cyclohexanedionedioxime (NioxH2) and 4,4′-bipyridine (bpy) resulted in similar binuclear coordination compounds of the general formula [M2(NioxH2)2(X)4(H2O)2(bpy)], where M = Cd and X = HCOO− for 1; M = Zn, Cd and X = CH3COO− for 2 and 3, respectively. When the corresponding sulfate salts were used as precursors in the synthesis, a dioxime-containing one-dimensional (1D) coordination polymer with the chemical formula [Cd(NioxH2)(SO4)·(bpy)](NioxH2)·(H2O)3 (4) was obtained with Cd. All compounds were characterized by X-ray diffraction and spectroscopic techniques, and the thermogravimetric data are presented solely for compound 4. The experimental results demonstrate the successful strategy of using “metal oxime” building blocks in order to design new multinuclear complexes. The study has shown that the geometry and size of the corresponding anions together with their coordinating and hydrogen-bonding properties are essential in determining the final structures.

When the corresponding sulfate salts were used as precursors in the synthesis, a dioxime-containing one-dimensional (1D) coordination polymer with the chemical formula [Cd(NioxH2)(SO4)⋅(bpy)](NioxH2)⋅(H2O)3 (4) was obtained with Cd. The study has shown that the geometry and size of the corresponding anions together with their coordinating and hydrogen-bonding properties are essential in determining the final structures.

elements.content: The paper presents an approach to construct Cd(II) and Zn(II) coordination compounds of different dimensionality with the use of neutral chelating dioxime, 4,4′-bipyridine, and carboxylate or sulfate anions. Four new dioxime-containing coordination compounds, three binuclear and one polymeric, have been prepared and structurally characterized by X-ray crystallography. The ability of dioxime to participate in strong intramolecular hydrogen bonding with the coordinating anions may be considered as an important factor that influences the final structure.

elements.content: During the past two decades, coordination chemistry of metal oximes/oximates has been undergoing an exciting renaissance with potential applications in fields like bioinorganic or magneto-chemistry. The undisputable advantage of this class of organic ligands is their ability to coordinate to the metal center in neutral or deprotonated modes giving rise to neutral or charged species, which show different dimensionality. A fairly large number of recent reviews cover the different aspects of chemistry of oxime/oximato metal compounds including the various synthetic strategies and their analytical applications.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

During the past two decades, coordination chemistry of metal oximes/oximates has been undergoing an exciting renaissance with potential applications in fields like bioinorganic or magneto-chemistry. The undisputable advantage of this class of organic ligands is their ability to coordinate to the metal center in neutral or deprotonated modes giving rise to neutral or charged species, which show different dimensionality. A fairly large number of recent reviews cover the different aspects of chemistry of oxime/oximato metal compounds including the various synthetic strategies and their analytical applications.

elements.content: The mononuclear alkylcobaloximes were the first class of compounds studied because they were considered very important coenzyme B12 models. The flexibility of their equatorial oxime ligands is quite similar to that of corrin in the natural cofactor. Complexes with classic oximes, dimethylglyoxime (dmgH2), 1,2-cyclohexanedionedioxime (NioxH2), and other alkyl, aryl-substituted oximes have also been widely studied. In this direction, attention has been primary drawn toward zero-dimensional complexes, mainly with Co(III) and its group analogues where the neutral ligands or monodeprotonated oximate anions form the central metal symmetric or asymmetric platform leading to neutral or cationic species. In this context, our previous research in oxime chemistry has been devoted to mononuclear Co dioximes/dioximates together with various ligands (1,10-phenathroline, pyridine, thiourea, ammine) on the apical metal coordinates. For Cu(II) our attempts to obtain a coordination compound using 4,4′-bipyridine (bpy) molecule as a linker between two robust metaldioximate units resulted in mono- and binuclear crystalline products of the compositions [Cu2(dpgH)4·(bpy)]2·DMF, [Cu2(dmgH)4·(bpy)]2·4dmgH2, and [Cu2(dmgH)4·(bpy)]·[Cu(dmgH)2·(bpy)]·(bpy)·2dmgH2, (dpgH2 = diphenylglyoxime) where the binuclear complex hosts either solvent molecules or a mixture of initial reagents (dmgH2, bpy) together with the monomeric complex [Cu(dmgH)2·(bpy)]. The main impediment in order to increase the compounds’ dimensionality up to at least a 1D polymer is the square−pyramidal geometry of the copper atom. Indeed, the copper coordination geometry in these binuclear complexes shows a deviation from the equatorial plane similar to those reported by Bishop and co-workers for mononuclear Cu(II) dioximate complexes.

elements.content: To the best of our knowledge, the well-known d10 Zn(II) and Cd(II) metal ions attracted insignificant attention in oxime chemistry despite the fact that they exhibit different structures and can lead to good luminescent properties. A literature overview indicates a more detailed investigation and exploitation of Zn(II)-based compounds than Cd(II) ones. This can be explained by the diversity of the Zn(II) coordination cores that can expand from a tetrahedral to an octahedral one, whereas the Cd(II) environment remains predominately octahedral. The most used oximes in Zn(II) and Cd(II) coordination chemistry are summarized in Scheme .

elements.content: The mononuclear Zn(II) complexes with neutral mono- and dioximes (Scheme a−e) as auxiliary ligands have been synthesized and studied in the presence of inorganic and organic anions. The phenanthrolinedicarbaldehyde dioxime (Scheme b) as a polydentate ligand and its complexes with both metals were found to be potential agents for nucleic acid hydrolysis. In the case of metalation with cadmium nitrate, it acts as a tetradentate ligand to give a pentagonal−bipyramidal structure. Dissociation of the oxime group into an oximate, which acts as an anionic bridging ligand, was observed in the case of metalation with zinc acetate thus giving rise to dimers and/or polymers. Di- and trinuclear heterometallic complexes including Zn and both the classic and modified mono- and dioxime ligands have shown great interest in the field of magneto-chemistry for the synthesis of single-molecule magnets (SMMs). The intensive study on exchange interactions covers the linear trinuclear complexes dealing specifically with the case of the d3d10d3 metal electronic configuration. The above objective has been realized by synthesizing isostructural and isoelectronic linear complexes CrIIIZnIICrIII and MnIVZnIIMnIV containing three oximato anions (Scheme d−f) as bridging ligands where the central divalent metal ion is redox inactive. The compounds obtained are isostructural in the sense that they all contain a terminal metal ion in a distorted octahedral environment (e.g., MN3O3) and a second hexa-coordinated metal ion M in a trigonal−prismatic MN6 geometry. Analysis of the susceptibility data indicates the presence of intramolecular ferro- and antiferromagnetic exchange interactions. The use of di-2-pyridyl ketone oxime (Scheme h)/X− “blends” (X− = PhCO2 −, N3 −, NCO−, acac−, NCS−) with zinc yielded a family of polynuclear (from tetra- to octanuclear) “inverse metal crown ethers”. The use of oximate ligands leads to a propeller structure, and two metal ions are in distorted O2N4 octahedral environments, whereas the remaining ones are in highly distorted tetrahedral or trigonal bipyramidal environments. In these coordination polyhedra, the zinc atoms, rather than oxygen atoms, point toward the central cavity, which can accommodate anions.

elements.content: Surprisingly, in spite of considerable attention drawn to the polymetallic coordination architecture, the oxime building block, although being suitable to provide a robust metal coordination core, is poorly elaborated to generate the polymeric host structures. Similar to the recent approach used for the synthesis of wheel-and-axle smart materials useful for the storage of small molecules (primary solvents) with a dibenzoylmethanate metal platform and bridging 4,4′-bipyridine molecule, the oxime/oximate platform would be a candidate in order to generate compounds of this type and showing different dimensionality. The known reaction products of Zn(II) and Cd(II) salts with the linear bifunctional bpy ligand and its longer analogues are known to form several types of coordination networks that range from 0D binuclear and trinuclear complexes to 1D networks (ladders, linear chains, helices, and railroads), 2D networks (square and rectangular grids, brick-wall and bilayers), and 3D networks (octahedral and diamondoid). The formation of the networks depends upon the presence of the guest, the coordination mode of the metal atom, the type of anions present, and the metal to ligand ratio. Papatriantafyllopoulou and co-workers have successfully obtained a 1D network by combination of a Zn (or Cd) metal center, 2-pyridyl oxime ligand (Scheme i) as an equatorial metal platform, and an aromatic amine. Apart from this single example, the Zn and Cd oxime polymeric chemistry remains entirely unexplored, particularly in the field of classic dioximes. To fill this gap, we intended to synthesize polymeric coordination compounds starting from the Zn(II) and Cd(II) halides, formates, acetates, or sulfates, 1,2-cyclohexyldionedioxime (NioxH2), and potentially bridging bpy ligand.

elements.content: This contribution presents synthesis, spectroscopic, and X-ray diffraction studies for three 0D and one 1D novel Zn and Cd mixed-ligand dioxime complexes, [Cd2(NioxH2)2(HCOO)4(H2O)2(bpy)] (1), [Zn2(NioxH2)2(CH3COO)4(H2O)2(bpy)] (2), [Cd2(NioxH2)2(CH3COO)4(H2O)2(bpy)] (3), and [Cd(NioxH2)(SO4) (bpy)](NioxH2).(H2O)3 (4). The thermogravimetric data are presented solely for compound 4.

elements.content: Cadmium salts are carcinogenic and toxic. All reagents and solvents were obtained from commercial sources and were used without further purification. Elemental analyses were performed on an Elementar Analysensysteme GmbH Vario El III elemental analyzer. The IR spectra were obtained in Vaselin on a FT IR Spectrum-100 Perkin-Elmer spectrometer in the range of 400−4000 cm−1. Absorption spectra were recorded on a UV/vis Lambda 25 Perkin-Elmer spectrometer. Luminescence characteristics were recorded on a Laser LGI-21 (λ = 337 nm, room temperature, monochromator MDR -23, oscilograf C1-73, FAU − 100), Thermogravimetric analysis-differential thermal analysis (TGA-DTA) measurements for sample 4 were performed by heating from 25 to 1000 °C at a rate of 5 °C min−1 on a Perkin-Elmer differential thermal analyzer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General Procedures. WARNING

Cadmium salts are carcinogenic and toxic. All reagents and solvents were obtained from commercial sources and were used without further purification. Elemental analyses were performed on an Elementar Analysensysteme GmbH Vario El III elemental analyzer. The IR spectra were obtained in Vaselin on a FT IR Spectrum-100 Perkin-Elmer spectrometer in the range of 400-4000 cm-1. Absorption spectra were recorded on a UV/vis Lambda 25 Perkin-Elmer spectrometer. Luminescence characteristics were recorded on a Laser LGI-21 (λ = 337 nm, room temperature, monochromator MDR -23, oscilograf C1-73, FAU - 100), Thermogravimetric analysis-differential thermal analysis (TGA-DTA) measurements for sample 4 were performed by heating from 25 to 1000 °C at a rate of 5 °C min-1 on a Perkin-Elmer differential thermal analyzer.

elements.content: To Cd(HCOO)2·2H2O (119.5 mg, 0.5 mmol) dissolved in 10 mL of water was added NioxH2 (142.15 mg, 1 mmol) dissolved in 20 mL of methanol, and bpy (40 mg, 0.25 mmol) in 10 mL of methanol. The reaction mixture was boiled for ∼10 min. From the beige solution, the crystals of needle habitus were precipitated. Yield: ∼35%. Anal. Calc. for Cd2C26H36N6O14, %: C, 35.43; H, 4.12; N, 9.53. Found C, 35.32; H, 4.09; N, 9.47. UV−vis in methanol [λmax, nm (ε, dm3 M−1 cm−1)]: 240 (29004). The IR (Vaselin) (cm−1) ν = 3187(w), 1630(w), 1607(s), 1537(m), 1494(m), 1419(m), 1324(w), 1225(m), 1098(v.s), 1052(v.s), 1044(v.s), 973(m), 901(w), 815(s), 615(w).

elements.content: Data were collected on a Nonius diffractometer equipped with a CCD area detector and a graphite monochromator utilizing Mo Kα radiation. Final unit cell dimensions were obtained and refined on an entire data set. All calculations to solve the structures and to refine the model proposed were carried out with the programs SHELXS97 and SHELXL97. In 3 two carbon atoms of cyclohexyl ring were refined to be disordered with the equal occupancies. The carbon bounded H atoms were placed in calculated positions and were treated using a riding model approximation with U iso(H) = 1.2U eq(C), while the oxygen bounded H-atoms were found from differential Fourier maps at an intermediate stage of the refinement and their positions were constrained using the AFIX 83 instruction in SHELXL for oxime groups, while for water hydrogens the O−H and H···H distances were restrained to be 0.86(1) and 1.46(1) Å, respectively. These hydrogen atoms were refined with isotropic displacement parameter U iso(H) = 1.5U eq(O). The X-ray data and the details of the refinement for 1−4 are summarized in Table , the selected geometric parameters are given in Table , and hydrogen-bonding geometry is given in Table . The figures were produced using Mercury.

X-ray Crystallography

Data were collected on a Nonius diffractometer equipped with a CCD area detector and a graphite monochromator utilizing Mo Kα radiation. Final unit cell dimensions were obtained and refined on an entire data set. All calculations to solve the structures and to refine the model proposed were carried out with the programs SHELXS97 and SHELXL97. In 3 two carbon atoms of cyclohexyl ring were refined to be disordered with the equal occupancies. The carbon bounded H atoms were placed in calculated positions and were treated using a riding model approximation with U iso(H) = 1.2U eq(C), while the oxygen bounded H-atoms were found from differential Fourier maps at an intermediate stage of the refinement and their positions were constrained using the AFIX 83 instruction in SHELXL for oxime groups, while for water hydrogens the O-H and H⋅⋅⋅H distances were restrained to be 0.86(1) and 1.46(1) Å, respectively. These hydrogen atoms were refined with isotropic displacement parameter U iso(H) = 1.5U eq(O). The X-ray data and the details of the refinement for 1-4 are summarized in Table , the selected geometric parameters are given in Table , and hydrogen-bonding geometry is given in Table . The figures were produced using Mercury.

The oxime moiety (−C(R)NO−) combined with a coordination site for metal ion represents a bridge between coordination complexes and supramolecular assembly. Since hydrogen bonding is presently one of the best known strategies to build supramolecular arrays in a controlled way, it is of utmost importance to understand the mechanism of exchange interactions mediated by hydrogen bonding in conjunction with oxime ligands, which are well-known for their hydrogen bonding capabilities. The nature of the anions also plays an important role in the structural control of the self-assembly. Carboxylate anions can coordinate to the metal center in monodentate, bidentate modes as well as in a bridging mode, while sulfate anion has even more versatile coordination modes that can lead to a diversity of frameworks. This is most important when the ligand system is neutral, as the anions can direct the self-assembly by either coordinating to the metal center or acting as noncoordinating counterions templates. The crucial influence of anions on the structures 1−4 is demonstrated below.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

The oxime moiety (-C(R)NO-) combined with a coordination site for metal ion represents a bridge between coordination complexes and supramolecular assembly. Since hydrogen bonding is presently one of the best known strategies to build supramolecular arrays in a controlled way, it is of utmost importance to understand the mechanism of exchange interactions mediated by hydrogen bonding in conjunction with oxime ligands, which are well-known for their hydrogen bonding capabilities. The nature of the anions also plays an important role in the structural control of the self-assembly. Carboxylate anions can coordinate to the metal center in monodentate, bidentate modes as well as in a bridging mode, while sulfate anion has even more versatile coordination modes that can lead to a diversity of frameworks. This is most important when the ligand system is neutral, as the anions can direct the self-assembly by either coordinating to the metal center or acting as noncoordinating counterions templates. The crucial influence of anions on the structures 1-4 is demonstrated below.

elements.content: The following series of experiments have been carried out: (1) M(HCOO)2 (M = Zn, Cd) + NioxH2 + bpy in the molar ratio 2:4:1. For Cd the reaction resulted in a binuclear complex of the composition [Cd2(NioxH2)2(HCOO)4·(H2O)2(bpy)] (1). No crystals suitable for X-ray study were obtained for Zn. (2) M(CH3COO)2 (M = Zn, Cd) + NioxH2 + bpy in the same molar ratio in the presence of CH3COONa. For both metals the reaction resulted in binuclear complex of the composition [M2(NioxH2)2(CH3COO)4·(H2O)2(bpy)] (2, 3) studied by X-ray diffraction. (3) The interaction in the system MSO4 (M = Zn, Cd) + NioxH2 + bpy in the same molar ratio in a buffer-free reaction medium in approximately the same synthetic conditions resulted in two types of 1D polymers, [Cd(NioxH2)(SO4)(bpy)]·(NioxH2)·(H2O)3 (4) (no crystals suitable for X-ray study were obtained for Zn) and the dioxime free [M(bpy)(SO4)·(H2O)3]·2H2O for Zn(II) and Cd(II). (4) When the CdHal2 (Hal = F, Cl, Br, J) was used as an initial salt no new crystals suitable for further investigation were obtained.
elements.clean_text:
Syntheses

The following series of experiments have been carried out: (1) M(HCOO)2 (M = Zn, Cd) + NioxH2 + bpy in the molar ratio 2:4:1. For Cd the reaction resulted in a binuclear complex of the composition [Cd2(NioxH2)2(HCOO)4⋅(H2O)2(bpy)] (1). No crystals suitable for X-ray study were obtained for Zn. (2) M(CH3COO)2 (M = Zn, Cd) + NioxH2 + bpy in the same molar ratio in the presence of CH3COONa. For both metals the reaction resulted in binuclear complex of the composition [M2(NioxH2)2(CH3COO)4⋅(H2O)2(bpy)] (2, 3) studied by X-ray diffraction. (3) The interaction in the system MSO4 (M = Zn, Cd) + NioxH2 + bpy in the same molar ratio in a buffer-free reaction medium in approximately the same synthetic conditions resulted in two types of 1D polymers, [Cd(NioxH2)(SO4)(bpy)]⋅(NioxH2)⋅(H2O)3 (4) (no crystals suitable for X-ray study were obtained for Zn) and the dioxime free [M(bpy)(SO4)⋅(H2O)3]⋅2H2O for Zn(II) and Cd(II). (4) When the CdHal2 (Hal = F, Cl, Br, J) was used as an initial salt no new crystals suitable for further investigation were obtained.

elements.content: The discussion is restrained to the most important vibrations in the 400−4000 cm−1 region. IR spectra for 1−4 contain bands typical for oxime group, ν(OH) in the range 3200−3000 cm−1; ν(CN) at 1600 and ν(C−O) in the region 1070−1080 cm−1, ν(N−OH) in the region 950−980 cm−1. The υ(CN) vibration of oxime is assigned to the medium bands in the wavenumber region of 1533−1606 cm−1 and is partially overlapping with sharp, medium intensity bands ranging from 1600 cm−1 to 1200 cm−1 that correspond to the stretching modes of ν(CC) and ν(CN) vibrations of the coordinated bpy ligand. The υs(CC) stretch at 1491 cm−1 can also be attibuted to this ligand. Features corresponding to the puckering of the aromatic rings are observed in the region between 820 cm−1 and 600 cm−1. Asymmetric and symmetric C−O stretching modes of the fully deprotonated carboxylate anions coincide with the strong broadened bands at 1600 cm−1. The presence of acetate ions is indicated by the stretching vibrations δ(CH3) at 1431, 1335 cm−1 for 2; 1342, 1320 cm−1 for 3 as well as ρr(CH3) at 1040 (2), and 1035 cm−1 (3). Besides these stretchings, it was detected the υ(COO) band at 1537 (1), 1550 (2), and 1533 cm−1 (3), and also π(COO) at 615−613 cm−1 for all three compounds. The symmetry of sulfato group is close to C 3v in 4. The bands typical for sulfate anion were observed in the 1130−1080 cm−1 and 680−610 cm−1 regions. The first absorption peak is intense and broad while the second is rather weak and narrow. The bands at 1130 (overlapping with the N−Ooxime stretch) and 1080 cm−1 can be assigned to the ν3 modes, while the bands at 712, 629, and 610 cm−1 correspond to the ν4 modes. The metal−ligand stretching vibrations M−O−C were observed at ∼1980 cm−1, υ(M−O)+, and υ(C−C) at ∼518 cm−1, υ(M−N) were observed at ∼420 cm−1. The single transition that has been observed in the UV region is at about 240 nm for 1−4 and is likely due to the metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT).

IR Spectroscopic Characterization

The discussion is restrained to the most important vibrations in the 400-4000 cm-1 region. IR spectra for 1-4 contain bands typical for oxime group, ν(OH) in the range 3200-3000 cm-1; ν(CN) at 1600 and ν(C-O) in the region 1070-1080 cm-1, ν(N-OH) in the region 950-980 cm-1. The υ(CN) vibration of oxime is assigned to the medium bands in the wavenumber region of 1533-1606 cm-1 and is partially overlapping with sharp, medium intensity bands ranging from 1600 cm-1 to 1200 cm-1 that correspond to the stretching modes of ν(CC) and ν(CN) vibrations of the coordinated bpy ligand. The υs(CC) stretch at 1491 cm-1 can also be attibuted to this ligand. Features corresponding to the puckering of the aromatic rings are observed in the region between 820 cm-1 and 600 cm-1. Asymmetric and symmetric C-O stretching modes of the fully deprotonated carboxylate anions coincide with the strong broadened bands at 1600 cm-1. The presence of acetate ions is indicated by the stretching vibrations δ(CH3) at 1431, 1335 cm-1 for 2; 1342, 1320 cm-1 for 3 as well as ρr(CH3) at 1040 (2), and 1035 cm-1 (3). Besides these stretchings, it was detected the υ(COO) band at 1537 (1), 1550 (2), and 1533 cm-1 (3), and also π(COO) at 615-613 cm-1 for all three compounds. The symmetry of sulfato group is close to C 3v  in 4. The bands typical for sulfate anion were observed in the 1130-1080 cm-1 and 680-610 cm-1 regions. The first absorption peak is intense and broad while the second is rather weak and narrow. The bands at 1130 (overlapping with the N-Ooxime stretch) and 1080 cm-1 can be assigned to the ν3 modes, while the bands at 712, 629, and 610 cm-1 correspond to the ν4 modes. The metal-ligand stretching vibrations M-O-C were observed at ~1980 cm-1, υ(M-O)+, and υ(C-C) at ~518 cm-1, υ(M-N) were observed at ~420 cm-1. The single transition that has been observed in the UV region is at about 240 nm for 1-4 and is likely due to the metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT).

elements.content: In the binuclear unit, each Cd(II) cation is hexacoordinated by three oxygen and three nitrogen atoms in a square bipyramid environment. Its basal plane is made up by a bidentate NioxH2 molecule and two monodentate formate anions; a water molecule and a bidentate bpy ligand occupy the apical sites, bpy acting as a bridging ligand to a symmetry-related metal atom. The neutral NioxH2 coordinates in a typical bidentate mode through its oxime nitrogen atoms, thus leading to the formation of a five-membered chelate ring around the metal core with a N1−Cd1−N2 angle of 66.86(13)° and slightly asymmetric Cd−N distances of 2.357(4) and 2.372(4) Å, respectively. Two crystallographically independent formate anions coordinate in a monodentate mode via O3 and O5 atoms and occupy the two other vertices of the basal plane with a O3−Cd1−O5 angle of 87.77(14)° and Cd−O distances of 2.221(3) and 2.224(4) Å, respectively. The N2O2 equatorial atoms are almost planar and the deviation of the cadmium atom from this plane is 0.022. The axial Cd1−O1W distance of 2.317(3) is insignificantly longer than the equatorial Cd−O distances, while the Cd1−N3 of 2.351(4) Å with the apical bpy nitrogen atom is the shortest among the three Cd−N distances. The hydrogen atoms of oxime groups attached to O1 and O2 and the HCOO− anions form two seven-membered chelate rings via O−H···O hydrogen bonds with O···O separations of 2.584(5) and 2.624(5) Å, respectively (Table ). The dihedral angle between the two mean planes of these rings is 10.7°. These chelate rings show a slightly different geometry: in the O1/N1/Cd1/O3/C7/O4 ring the maximal deviation from the mean plane is 0.049 Å, while it is 0.106 Å in the O2/N2/Cd1/O5/C8/O6 ring. The bpy molecule is planar and displays a typical T-shape arrangement in the equatorial plane of the metal atom. The Cd1···Cd1′ distance in the molecule is equal to 11.746 Å, which is a typical value found for two cadmium atoms linked through a bpy ligand.

elements.content: The isomorphous compounds 2 and 3 crystallize in monoclinic space group C2/m. Only [Cd2(NioxH2)2·(CH3COO)4(bpy)·2H2O] (3) will be further discussed. The molecule 3 has a C 2h symmetry with the metal atom sitting on a mirror plane that is also going through the middle of the C1−C1′ and C3−C3′ bonds of the NioxH2 molecule. Figure depicts its overall view. The substitution of formate by acetate anion does not essentially change the organization of the binuclear unit.

elements.content: Because of symmetry, the metal coordination core is more symmetric than in 1 and is characterized by two couples of equal Cd−O and Cd−N distances of 2.235(3) and 2.366(3) Å in the basal plane and Cd1−O1W of 2.313(4) and Cd1−N2 of 2.389(4) Å distances with the apical ligands. The N2O2 atoms lie exactly in the same plane and atom Cd1 has a deviation of 0.044 Å from this plane. The hydroxyl hydrogen atoms form two identical seven-membered H-bonded rings with acetate anions via O−H···O hydrogen bond, O1−H1A···O3 2.587(5) (Table ). The Cd1...Cd1′ distance within the molecule is 11.837 Å (in 2 the Zn···Zn distance is equal to 11.541 Å). In 1−3 the cyclohexyl ring of the NioxH2 molecule adopts a half-boat conformation. 2 and 3 differ by the level of disorder of the cyclohexyl ring, which tends to be more severe for compound 3.

elements.content: The crystal packing differs in 1 and 3 (Figure , Table ). In 1 the binuclear molecules form a hydrogen-bonded 3D network. In 3 the water molecule in the apical position of the metal polyhedron demonstrates its cross-linking function being involved in hydrogen bonding with oxygen atoms of acetate anions via two R2 2(16) H-bonded cycles giving rise to the ordered layer where each binuclear unit is involved in eight OH···O hydrogen bonds and is linked with four symmetry-related neighbors. The same H-bond directing layer ordering of binuclear (M2F10·2H2O)2− (M = Zr, Hf) anions was previously reported in crystalline structures formed with crown ethers.

elements.content: The binuclear complexes mediated by bpy as a bridging ligand are rather numerous for Zn(II) in its octahedral, square−pyramidal or tetrahedral environment, but very few examples of Cd(II) in octahedral or square−pyramidal environment are reported. Furthermore, several examples of controllable synthetic pathways from 1D aggregates to 0D bi- or trinuclear units are known for Zn compounds. On the basis of these examinations, we intend to modify our synthetic procedure in order to substitute apical water molecule in 1−3 by a bpy molecule and thus generate aggregates of higher dimensionalities.
elements.clean_text: The binuclear complexes mediated by bpy as a bridging ligand are rather numerous for Zn(II) in its octahedral, square-pyramidal or tetrahedral environment, but very few examples of Cd(II) in octahedral or square-pyramidal environment are reported. Furthermore, several examples of controllable synthetic pathways from 1D aggregates to 0D bi- or trinuclear units are known for Zn compounds. On the basis of these examinations, we intend to modify our synthetic procedure in order to substitute apical water molecule in 1-3 by a bpy molecule and thus generate aggregates of higher dimensionalities.

elements.content: To conclude this section, compounds 1−3 are rather rare representatives of mixed-ligand metal dioximes that have been obtained by substitution of coordinating water molecules by one NioxH2 molecule. So far the combination of dioximes and acetate ligands in the metal coordination core has been limited to the triangular Pt(II) cluster complexes [Pt3(CH3COO)4(NioxH)2(NioxH2)] and [Pt3(CH3COO)4(dmgH)2(dmgH2)] where the transformation of the initial acetate salt is associated with in-plane ligand substitution and the acetate ligand chelates two metal centers, and to Zn(TRISOXH3)(CH3COO)2 (TRISOXH3 is tris(1-propan-2-onyl oxime) amine, Scheme j), where the TRISOXH3 and two monodentate acetate ligands form a N3O2 metal coordination core, additionally stabilized by the intramolecular O−H···O(CH3COO−) hydrogen bonding with participation of oxime hydroxyl group similar to 1−3. In 1−3 one dioxime molecule and two carboxylate residues act in a concerted fashion via a system of H-bonding to resemble the geometry of two coordinated monodeprotonated [NioxH]− anions (Figures a and a).

elements.content: Before starting further discussion one should mention that alongside the polymeric structure 4 discussed below we obtained, in the same synthetic conditions, dioxime free polymeric compounds of general formula [M(bpy)(SO4)·(H2O)3]·2H2O for Zn(II) and Cd(II) isomorphous to the Cu(II) analogue of the same composition. Complexes represent 1D polymers in which bpy acts as a bridging ligand supporting the formation of infinite [M(bpy)(SO4)·(H2O)3] chains (Figure a). Each metal atom is surrounded by two bpy molecules, three water molecules, and one SO4 2− anion which alternates with one water molecule in the structure. Sulfate anion coordinates to the metal in μ1-mode and participates in hydrogen bonding with coordinated and solvated water molecules. The adjacent chains are rotated by 60° to produce hexagonal channels that are occupied by water molecules. The packing diagram reveals a helical structure supported by the hydrogen bonding between the alternative sulfate anion and water molecules (Figure b).

elements.content: The X-ray diffraction results for 4 shows that all of the Cd(II) atoms in the [Cd(NioxH2)(SO4)(bpy)](NioxH2)·(H2O)3 polymer are equivalent. Figure depicts the coordination geometry of Cd(II) center. Each Cd(II) ion binds one two-coordinate NioxH2 molecule, two two-coordinate sulfato-anions constitute the basal ligands, and two bpy molecules act as axial ligands leading to the formation of a square bipyramidal N4O2-coordination core. The structure is centrosymmetric with the inversion center lying inside the cavity built up by two metal ions and two μ2-oxygen atoms of the two SO4 2− anions. The NioxH2 molecule coordinates in a typical bidentate mode via two nitrogen atoms. Four Cd−N distances fall in the range 2.330(5)−2.366(5) Å, and are in agreement with the distances calculated for compound 3. The Cd atom deviates 0.069(2) Å from the basal plane defined by N1, N2, O3, and O3′ atoms. The Cd1−O3 and Cd1′−O3 bond distances with the oxygen atom from a sulfato anion are equal to 2.273(4) and 2.295(4) Å, respectively, giving rise to a rhomb with the longest diagonal Cd1···Cd1′ (symmetry transformation for Cd1′ is 1 − x, 2 − y, 2 − z) of 3.533 Å. The bimetallic platform (Figure a) is in a T-shaped arrangement with respect to the axial bpy ligands. It is made of a combination of one four-membered and two five-membered metallocycles and four H-bonded 7-membered H-bonded chelate rings where one oxygen (O3) from the SO4 2− anion is coordinating and two others (O4 and O5) are involved in the hydrogen bond scheme. The mean deviations from the mean planes Cd1/N1/N2/C1/C6 (plane A), Cd1/O3/Cd1′/O3′ (plane B), Cd1/N1/O1/H1A/O4/S1/O3 (plane C), and Cd1/N2/O2/H2C/O5/S1/O3 (plane D) are 0.054, 0.0, 0.229, and 0.217 Å, respectively. The dihedral angles A/B, A/C, A/D, B/C, C/D equal to 9.27(7), 6.37(6), 3.27(4), 14.67 and 4.22(5)°, respectively. The distance C3···C4′ between the most distant atoms in the equatorial platform equals 14.522 Å.

elements.content: The S1−O distances demonstrate the pronounced asymmetry. With the largest value of 1.520(4) Å found for S1−O3, as the two metals bridging part, and three other S−O distances gradually increasing from 1.450(4) to 1.463(5) Å, the delocalized sesquilateral bond order is clearly established. For SO4 2− two examples of such inclusion were found in bis(μ2-sulfato-O,O) -bis(2-formylpyridine thiosemicarbazonato-N,N′,S)-di-Cu(II) and bis(μ3-sulfato-O,O,O′)-bis(μ2-N,N,N′-tris(2-pyridylmethyl)-1,3-diaminopropan-2-olato)-tetra-Cu(II) diperchlorate with Cu···Cu separation of 3.310 and 3.278 Å, respectively, and where generation of binuclear and tetranuclear aggregates where observed. On the other hand, although the CSD statistics indicates that the binuclear Cd2O2 building unit is met rather frequently (about 200 hits) with the oxygen atom of water molecule, hydroxyl group, phenoxide group, acetate or nitrate anion being in a bridging function, only two examples, bis(μ2-sulfato-O,O,O′,O′′)-bis(2,2′:6′2′-terpyridine-N,N′,N′′)-di-Cd(II) dihydrate and bis(μ2-sulfito-O,O,O′,O′′)-bis(2,4,6-tris(2-pyridyl)-1,3,5-triazine-N,N′,N′′)-di-Cd(II) octahydrate, show a case of sulfate and sulfite anion inclusion in bridging modes (Scheme ) with Cd···Cd distances of 4.028 and 3.710 Å, respectively.

elements.content: The use of the sulfate anion as a polydentate ligand in coordination chemistry is widely used nowadays. The generalization of modes of SO4 2− inclusion in coordination polymers based on Harris notation for the multidentate ligands are available. We have restricted our examinations to Zn(II) and Cd(II) cations and summarized the commonly met modes of SO4 2− involvement in Scheme .

elements.content: Figure demonstrates the association of Cd(II) binuclear units and bidentate bpy ligands, which results in a railway-type chain. Similar type Cd-based 1D polymers were previously reported with nitrate or acetate anion acting as a bridging ligand between two Cd centers. The chains are further combined in a 2D hydrogen-bonded network (Figure b) via an infinitive H-bonded water-rich column that shows alternating six-membered centrosymmetric H-bonded rings, (H2O)6 water homoclusters and (H2O)4(SO4)2 heteroclusters, with the R6 6(12),R6 6(16) sequence in graph set notation. The enclathrated NioxH2 molecules are attached via OH···O hydrogen bonding to sulfate anions and water molecules (Figure c, Table ).

elements.content: The thermal behavior of 4 was investigated by TGA. The TGA curve demonstrates some exo- and endo- effects. Complex 4 was heated to 1000 °C; the weight loss of over 7% between 50 and 80 °C corresponds to the loss of three water molecules of crystallization (7.68% calcd). Next weight loss is observed in the range 125−210 °C (∼20%) and corresponds to the departure of the uncoordinated NioxH2 molecule. Loss of weight at ∼235−350 °C characterizes the degradation of the coordinated NioxH2 molecule (∼20%). Decomposition of the bpy molecule occurs in the temperature range 350−440 °C (∼22%). The final loss likely corresponds to the formation of CdSO4 with a weight of 33% that of the initial compound (29.7% calcd).

elements.content: Irradiation of crystalline samples of 1−4 with ultraviolet light (λex = 300 nm) resulted in a broad visible light emission that appears to the naked eye as spanning from pale yellow to yellow-bluish for 1−3 and intense blue-violet emission centered on 395 nm for 4. Similar to other divalent Cd-based coordination polymers incorporating aromatic ligands, this emissive behavior is ascribed to π−π* transitions within the molecular orbital manifolds of pyridyl moieties.

Similar to other divalent Cd-based coordination polymers incorporating aromatic ligands, this emissive behavior is ascribed to π-π* transitions within the molecular orbital manifolds of pyridyl moieties.

elements.content: Finally, we present an approach to construct Cd(II) and Zn(II) coordination compounds of different dimensionality with the use of neutral chelating dioxime, 4,4′-bipyridine and carboxylate or sulfate anions. Four new coordination compounds, three binuclear and one polymeric, have been prepared and structurally characterized by X-ray crystallography. In the presence of the formate or acetate anions binuclear complexes [M2(NioxH2)2(X)4(H2O)2(bpy)] (M = Zn, Cd), (X = HCOO−, CH3COO−) were formed, with two carboxylate anions placed in an equatorial plane, coordinating the metal center in monodentate mode and forming strong hydrogen bonding interactions with the neutral dioxime ligand. We notice a structural similarity between complexes with the two monoanionic dioxime ligands in an equatorial plane and those formed by a neutral dioxime and two carboxylate anions. In contrast to the carboxylate ligands, in the presence of the sulfate anion a 1D polymeric structure [Cd(NioxH2)(SO4)(bpy)](NioxH2)·(H2O)3 was formed with the sulfate anion acting in a rarely met bridging mode. The ability of dioxime to participate in strong intramolecular hydrogen bonding with the coordinating anions may be considered as an important factor that influences the final structure. The future studies are aimed at enhancing this family of compounds and studying in detail their luminescence properties.

Four new coordination compounds, three binuclear and one polymeric, have been prepared and structurally characterized by X-ray crystallography. In the presence of the formate or acetate anions binuclear complexes [M2(NioxH2)2(X)4(H2O)2(bpy)] (M = Zn, Cd), (X = HCOO-, CH3COO-) were formed, with two carboxylate anions placed in an equatorial plane, coordinating the metal center in monodentate mode and forming strong hydrogen bonding interactions with the neutral dioxime ligand. We notice a structural similarity between complexes with the two monoanionic dioxime ligands in an equatorial plane and those formed by a neutral dioxime and two carboxylate anions. In contrast to the carboxylate ligands, in the presence of the sulfate anion a 1D polymeric structure [Cd(NioxH2)(SO4)(bpy)](NioxH2)⋅(H2O)3 was formed with the sulfate anion acting in a rarely met bridging mode. The ability of dioxime to participate in strong intramolecular hydrogen bonding with the coordinating anions may be considered as an important factor that influences the final structure. The future studies are aimed at enhancing this family of compounds and studying in detail their luminescence properties.

To Cd(HCOO)2·2H2O (119.5 mg, 0.5 mmol) dissolved in 10 mL of water was added NioxH2 (142.15 mg, 1 mmol) dissolved in 20 mL of methanol, and bpy (40 mg, 0.25 mmol) in 10 mL of methanol. The reaction mixture was boiled for ∼10 min. From the beige solution, the crystals of needle habitus were precipitated. Yield: ∼35%. Anal. Calc. for Cd2C26H36N6O14, %: C, 35.43; H, 4.12; N, 9.53. Found C, 35.32; H, 4.09; N, 9.47. UV−vis in methanol [λmax, nm (ε, dm3 M−1 cm−1)]: 240 (29004). The IR (Vaselin) (cm−1) ν = 3187(w), 1630(w), 1607(s), 1537(m), 1494(m), 1419(m), 1324(w), 1225(m), 1098(v.s), 1052(v.s), 1044(v.s), 973(m), 901(w), 815(s), 615(w).

To keep the neutral pH of the reaction medium CH3COONa was also added (40 mg, 0.5 mmol). The reaction mixture was boiled for 5 min. To Cd(CH3COO)2·2H2O (133 mg, 0.5 mmol) dissolved in 10 mL of water was added NioxH2 (142.15 mg, 1 mmol) dissolved in 20 mL of methanol, bpy (40 mg, 0.25 mmol) in 10 mL of methanol and CH3COONa (40 mg, 0.5 mmol). cln_elements.content:
The thermal behavior of 4 was investigated by TGA. The TGA curve demonstrates some exo- and endo- effects. Complex 4 was heated to 1000 °C; the weight loss of over 7% between 50 and 80 °C corresponds to the loss of three water molecules of crystallization (7.68% calcd). Next weight loss is observed in the range 125−210 °C (∼20%) and corresponds to the departure of the uncoordinated NioxH2 molecule. Loss of weight at ∼235−350 °C characterizes the degradation of the coordinated NioxH2 molecule (∼20%). Decomposition of the bpy molecule occurs in the temperature range 350−440 °C (∼22%). The final loss likely corresponds to the formation of CdSO4 with a weight of 33% that of the initial compound (29.7% calcd).

Crystallographic data for C10H18CdN2O9S, FW = 454.72, hexagonal, P61, λ = 0.71073 Å, a = 11.6597(9), b = 11.6597(9), c = 20.813(2) Å, γ = 120°, V = 2450.4(4) Å3, Z = 6, ρcalc = 1.849 g/cm3, μ = 1.511 mm−1, θ range 3.49−25.49°, GOF = 1.041 (R int = 0.0324), R 1 = 0.0665, wR 2 = 0.1840 for 2216 reflections with I > 2σ(I), R 1 = 0.0685, wR 2 = 0.1852 for all 2419 unique reflections. The crystal was refined in anisotropic-isotropic model as a racemic twin with the ratio of components as 66:33. One of the aromatic rings, sulfate anion and outer sphere water molecules exhibit extensive disorder. Hydrogen atoms of water molecules were not localized.

Schematic Diagram of Oximes and Dioximes Used in Zn(II) and Cd(II) Coordination Chemistry<xref rid="sch1-fn1"></xref>

Selected examples as deposited at CSD: (a) BOBHEF (Zn); (b) DUHHAP (Zn); DUHJAR, DUHJOF (both Cd); (c) LUFCOM (Zn); (e) TERQEM (Zn); (j) FIYSAI − all mononuclear complexes; (d) ADEKEZ (Cr, Zn), VONNER (Mn, Zn) (f) PAWYAN (Mn, Zn) − all trinuclear complexes (g) CEPZAY − tetranuclear complex; (h) AGODIJ, CAQGEH, CAQGIL, CAQGOR, CAQGUX (all − Zn) − tetranuclear complexes, CAQHAE, CAQHEI, CAQHIM (all − Zn) − pentanuclear complexes; (i) MEBSIW, QIQLAD − mononuclear complexes; MEBSOC, OHUGAZ − tetranuclear complexes (all −Zn).
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  Schematic Diagram of Oximes and Dioximes Used in Zn(II) and Cd(II) Coordination Chemistry      a Selected examples as deposited at CSD: (a) BOBHEF (Zn); (b) DUHHAP (Zn); DUHJAR, DUHJOF (both Cd); (c) LUFCOM (Zn); (e) TERQEM (Zn); (j) FIYSAI - all mononuclear complexes; (d) ADEKEZ (Cr, Zn), VONNER (Mn, Zn) (f) PAWYAN (Mn, Zn) - all trinuclear complexes (g) CEPZAY - tetranuclear complex; (h) AGODIJ, CAQGEH, CAQGIL, CAQGOR, CAQGUX (all - Zn) - tetranuclear complexes, CAQHAE, CAQHEI, CAQHIM (all - Zn) - pentanuclear complexes; (i) MEBSIW, QIQLAD - mononuclear complexes; MEBSOC, OHUGAZ - tetranuclear complexes (all -Zn).
